portfolio_name: State Highway Patrol Retirement System - Investment Policy Statement
doc_name: State Highway Patrol Retirement System - Investment Policy Statement.pdf

guidelines.text: The overall long-term investment objective is for the System is to earn 7.25% over a market cycle.
This investment objective should be achieved with the least required level of portfolio volatility.
The target allocation for Public Equity is 45.0%, with a range of 35% - 55%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Global Equity is 23.0%, with a range of 18% - 28%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for U.S. Equity is 22.0%, with a range of 17% - 27%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for International Equity is 0.0%, with a range of 0% - 5%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Alternative Investments is 30.0%, with a range of 20% - 40%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Absolute Return is 5.0%, with a range of 0% - 10%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Private Equity is 20.0%, with a range of 15% - 25%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Real Assets is 5.0%, with a range of 0% - 10%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Real Estate is 5.0%, with a range of 0% - 10%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Fixed Income is 20.0%, with a range of 10% - 30%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Core Fixed Income is 8.0%, with a range of 3% - 13%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Opportunistic fixed income is 9.0%, with a range of 4% - 14%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: The target allocation for Cash is 3.0%, with a range of 0% - 8%.
guidelines.provenance: ASSET ALLOCATION GUIDELINES, Long-Term Targets Table, page 4

guidelines.text: System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Common stocks
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Convertible preferred stocks
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: American depository receipts (ADRs) of non-U.S. companies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Stocks of non-U.S. companies (Ordinary shares)
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Equity collective pools, mutual funds, and exchange traded funds
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Tactical asset allocation strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Absolute return strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Long-short strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Hedge funds or hedge fund-of-fund strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Private equity and debt strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Timber investments
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Energy master limited partnerships
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Infrastructure strategies
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Alternative collective pools, mutual funds, and exchange traded funds
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: U.S. and non-U.S. public real estate (REITS)
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: U.S. and non-U.S. private real estate
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Real estate collective pools, mutual funds, and exchange traded funds
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: U.S. government and agency securities

guidelines.text: System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Treasury bills
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Commercial paper
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Banker's acceptances
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Repurchase agreements
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Certificates of deposit
System assets may invest in the following types of investments: Money market collective pools, mutual funds, and exchange traded funds
The investment objective of the System: 7.25% (actuarial rate of return)
A blended benchmark of market indices based on the targeted asset allocation for the System portfolio:
The benchmark for U.S. Equity is the Russell 3000 Index with a weight of 22%.
The benchmark for Global Equity is the MSCI ACWI Index with a weight of 23%.
The benchmark for Absolute Return is the HFRI Fund of Funds Composite Index with a weight of 5%.

structured.benchmark: HFRI Fund of Funds Composite Index

guidelines.text: The benchmark for Real Assets is the Real Assets Composite with a weight of 5%.
The benchmark for Private Equity is the Private Equity Composite with a weight of 20%.
The benchmark for Real Estate is the Real Estate Composite with a weight of 5%.
The benchmark for Core Fixed Income is the Bloomberg U.S. Aggregate Bond Index with a weight of 8%.
The benchmark for Global Opportunistic Fixed Income is the Credit Suisse Leveraged Loans Index with a weight of 9%.
The benchmark for Cash is the ML 91-Day T-Bill Index with a weight of 3%.
The System will be compared to a peer universe of similar sized public pension funds
The following guidelines only apply to separately managed accounts.

Mutual funds and collective vehicles are not expected to comply with these guidelines but rather are bound to their fund prospectus for mutual funds and ETFs or the governing documents for collective pools.
An equity manager may not: Hold more than 15% of the account value in a single issuer
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: An equity manager may not: Where a sector is greater than 10% of the benchmark, allow that sector to exceed 60% of the portfolio
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: An equity manager may not: Where a sector is 10% or less of the benchmark, allow that sector to exceed 40% of the portfolio
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: An equity manager may not: Invest in international-domiciled securities exceeding 20% of portfolio value in a domestic mandate
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: An equity manager may not: Allow one country to be more than 20 percentage points above the country weighting of the relative benchmark in an international mandate
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: An equity manager may not: Invest in emerging markets exceeding 35% of portfolio value in a developed international mandate
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Private placements
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Unregistered or restricted stock
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Derivatives
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Margin Trading/Short Sales
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Commodities
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Real Estate Property (excluding REITs)
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Guaranteed Insurance Contracts
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: Equity managers are prohibited from investing in the following: Securities issued by Highway Patrol Retirement System or its affiliates.
guidelines.provenance: SEPARATE ACCOUNT PORTFOLIO GUIDELINES, Equity, page 7

guidelines.text: A core fixed income allocation will be diversified as to type of security, issuer, coupon, and maturity.
Qualifying bonds, at the time of purchase, will be rated as investment-grade by at least two nationally recognized bond rating services.
Generally, the average maturity of a fixed income allocation will be ten years or less, although individual securities may be longer.

No more than ten percent of a fixed income allocation will be invested in the securities of any one issuer and no more than five percent in any one issue, with the exception of U.S. government securities.
Diversification of the bond portfolio will be accomplished by investing in a combination of U.S. government bonds, U.S. agency bonds, U.S. corporate bonds, high yield bonds, and non-U.S. bonds.
Managers are prohibited from using derivative instruments.
Investment Managers shall be selected in accordance with the Selection of Investment Managers and Agents Policy as well as the Manager Search and Termination Policy.

The Board will consider investments that enhance the welfare of the State of Ohio, and Ohio citizens, where such investments offer safety and quality of return comparable to other investments currently available.

Equal consideration will be given to investments otherwise qualifying under this section that involve minority-owned and controlled firms, or firms owned and controlled by women, either alone or in joint venture with other firms.

The Board will, at least annually, establish a policy with the goal to increase utilization of Ohio-qualified investment managers, when an Ohio-qualified investment manager offers quality, services, and safety comparable to other investment managers otherwise available.

The Board will, at least annually, establish a policy with the goal to increase utilization of Ohio-qualified agents for the execution of domestic equity and fixed income trades on behalf of the System, when an Ohio-qualified agent offers quality, services, and safety comparable to other agents otherwise available.
Investment managers are responsible for voting proxies and should be made in the best interest of investors.
The Investment Committee expects the purchase and sale of its securities to be made in a manner designed to receive the combination of best price and execution.
In separately managed equity accounts, HPRS investment managers are encouraged to use brokers that are under contract with HPRS to provide execution-only brokerage.
Every five years, these brokers will be reviewed;
the Board may consider issuing a Request for Proposal if it is deemed necessary.
An investment manager may be excused from the directed brokerage requirement if it can document favorable execution.
Asset allocation should be reviewed at least annually to ensure that the plan is on track to achieve the investment goals.
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9

guidelines.text: Asset allocation should be reviewed at least annually ... that all the major assumptions used to establish the plan remain reasonable.
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9

guidelines.text: A comprehensive review of asset allocation in the form of asset-liability modeling should be conducted every five years,
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9

guidelines.text: A comprehensive review of asset allocation in the form of asset-liability modeling should be conducted ... whenever a major structural change occurs in liabilities or investment assets.
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9

guidelines.text: An asset allocation plan may require reconsideration when it becomes apparent that the assets are not keeping pace with the liabilities of a plan.
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9

guidelines.text: To ensure the continued relevance of the guidelines and objectives, as established in this investment policy statement, the Board should review the investment policy annually, or as deemed necessary.
guidelines.provenance: Periodic Portfolio and Policy Reviews, page 9
